summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons Health Services Medication Summary for inmate Jeffrey Epstein covering his incarceration at the New York Metropolitan Correctional Center from July 7, 2019, to August 10, 2019. It details his prescribed medications, including laxatives, stool softeners, steroids, omega-3 supplements, and insulin, with dispensing records up to the day before his death.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The primary subject of the medical record, listed as an inmate at the New York MCC, for whom the medication summary was generated.

persons.name: Robert Beaudouin
persons.context: Listed as the prescribing doctor for one of Jeffrey Epstein's insulin prescriptions during his incarceration.

connections.description: Dr. Beaudouin was the prescribing physician for an insulin regimen for inmate Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Epstein Incarceration Period Begins
events.description: The start date of the medication summary report, marking Jeffrey Epstein's period of incarceration at the New York MCC covered by this document.

events.title: Medication Summary Generated
events.description: The date the Bureau of Prisons generated this medication summary report, which covers the period up to and including this date.

locations: New York Metropolitan Correctional Center (NYMâ€”NEW YORK MCC)
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was prescribed a regimen of medications including laxatives (Bisacodyl, Milk of Magnesia), stool softeners (Docusate Sodium), steroids (methylPREDNISolone), omega-3 supplements (Vascepa), and insulin during his final month of incarceration.
The document covers the period from July 7, 2019, to August 10, 2019, the day before Epstein was found dead in his cell.

Epstein's insulin prescriptions, including one prescribed by Dr. Robert Beaudouin, show a 'sliding scale' regimen and note '0 ML' was dispensed, indicating it may not have been administered or was recorded as such.
The record states Epstein 'Denied' having any allergies.
This is an official Bureau of Prisons health record, providing a factual account of prescribed medical treatment during a critical period.
